previous_statement: STRICTNESS FOR n>=3: When n >= 3, the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality in Step 1.5.3 is strict unless H_p and H_q are proportional (as vectors in R^n). Show that proportionality H_p(mu_i)/H_q(nu_i) = const for all i forces p and q to have identical gap ratios, which generically fails, giving strict inequality 1/Phi_n(r) > 1/Phi_n(p) + 1/Phi_n(q) for n >= 3.
new_statement:
STRICTNESS CHARACTERIZATION FOR 1/Phi_n SUPERADDITIVITY:

Complete analysis of when equality vs strict inequality holds in 1/Phi_n(p âŠž_n q) >= 1/Phi_n(p) + 1/Phi_n(q).

(a) n = 1: Trivial/vacuous (Phi_1 undefined for degree-1 polynomials).

(b) n = 2: EQUALITY ALWAYS HOLDS (unconditionally proved). Phi_2(p) = 2/(gap)^2 and gap(r)^2 = gap(p)^2 + gap(q)^2 (Pythagorean identity for MSS convolution at n=2). See child 1.5.4.1.

(c) n = 3: EQUALITY iff both p and q are equally-spaced. Equal-gap is the unique gap structure preserved by MSS convolution at n=3. Analytical proof provided. See child 1.5.4.2.

(d) n >= 4: STRICT INEQUALITY FOR ALL PAIRS. MSS convolution does not preserve equal-gap structure for n >= 4, so even the most symmetric pairs give strict inequality. Numerical evidence provided. See child 1.5.4.3.

CORRECTION: The original node statement (strict for all n >= 3) was incorrect. The n=3 equal-gap family gives exact equality.
